title: Can you still feel a limb that's gone? - Joshua W. Pate

options.text: Cortical homunculus

options.label: B
options.text: Somatosensory cortex

options.label: C
options.text: Phantom limb model

options.label: D
options.text: Neural pathway model

options.text: The amount of sensory input the brain receives from that body part

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The location of the body part

options.label: D
options.text: The function of the body part

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The increased sensitivity of the remaining nerve endings

options.label: C
options.text: Gaining insight into the subjective nature of reality

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

title: The "End Of History" Illusion - Bence Nanay

multiple-choice.question: What is the "End of History Illusion" in the context of individual lives?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that people can accurately predict their future preferences and values.

options.label: B
options.text: The concept that people tend to believe they will not change much in the future.

options.label: C
options.text: The notion that people's personalities and values are fixed at birth.

options.label: D
options.text: The theory that people's preferences and values change randomly over time.

multiple-choice.question: According to the research, what was the result when comparing the predicted changes to the reported changes across different age groups?

options.label: A
options.text: The predicted changes were accurate for the most part.

options.label: B
options.text: The predicted changes were slightly higher than the reported changes.

options.label: C
options.text: The predicted changes were overwhelmingly lower than the reported changes.

options.label: D
options.text: The predicted changes were the same as the reported changes.

multiple-choice.question: What is one consequence of the "End of History Illusion" in terms of decision-making?

options.label: A
options.text: People tend to underinvest in future choices based on present preferences.

options.label: B
options.text: People tend to overinvest in future choices based on present preferences.

options.label: C
options.text: People tend to make random decisions without considering their future preferences.

options.label: D
options.text: People tend to seek advice from others when making decisions.

multiple-choice.question: How much more are people willing to pay to see their current favorite musician ten years in the future compared to seeing their favorite musician from ten years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: 20% more

options.label: B
options.text: 40% more

options.label: C
options.text: 60% more

options.label: D
options.text: 80% more

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one implication of recognizing the "End of History Illusion" in our individual lives and the wider world?

options.label: A
options.text: We should never make long-term plans.

options.label: B
options.text: We should always prioritize our current preferences.

options.label: C
options.text: We should be open to the possibility of change and growth.

options.label: D
options.text: We should assume that the world will remain the same forever.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They would remain intact.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: They start to multiply and increase in number.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It triggers the release of dopamine and other neurotransmitters, creating pleasurable sensations.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of heart disease decreases by 25% after quitting smoking.

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of heart disease plummets to half after quitting smoking for one year.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Smoking has no effect on the body's ability to fight cancer.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: How exactly does binary code work? - José Américo N L F Freitas

multiple-choice.question: Why do computers use binary code?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is the most complex form of data storage.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a reliable way of storing data using only two options.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is the fastest form of data transmission.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is the most expensive form of data storage.

multiple-choice.question: How are numbers represented in binary code?

options.label: A
options.text: Each digit is multiplied by 10 raised to the value of its position.

options.label: B
options.text: Each digit is multiplied by 2 raised to the value of its position.

options.label: C
options.text: Each digit is multiplied by 5 raised to the value of its position.

options.label: D
options.text: Each digit is multiplied by 8 raised to the value of its position.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the UTF-8 standard in binary code?

options.label: A
options.text: To assign each character to a specific group of 8-digit binary strings.

options.label: B
options.text: To assign each number to a specific group of 8-digit binary strings.

options.label: C
options.text: To assign each color to a specific group of 8-digit binary strings.

options.label: D
options.text: To assign each sound to a specific group of 8-digit binary strings.

multiple-choice.question: How is sound stored in binary code?

options.label: A
options.text: By taking "snapshots" of sound waves every few seconds.

options.label: B
options.text: By taking "snapshots" of sound waves every few milliseconds.

options.label: C
options.text: By recording sound waves as a continuous stream of data.

options.label: D
options.text: By compressing sound waves into a single binary string.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of run-length encoding in binary code?

options.label: A
options.text: To compress data by recording repeated values as a single value.

options.label: B
options.text: To decompress data by recording repeated values as separate values.

options.label: C
options.text: To encrypt data by recording repeated values as a single value.

options.label: D
options.text: To decrypt data by recording repeated values as separate values.

options.text: Practice reflection, lecturing, and standardized testing

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker argue is a metaphor for all kids?

options.label: A
options.text: The senior who has checked out before the year's even begun

options.label: B
options.text: The empty desk in the back of an urban middle school's classroom

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker's daughter Riley

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker's students in general

options.label: B
options.text: To help her prepare for standardized tests

options.label: C
options.text: To grow her curiosity

options.label: D

title: How one scientist averted a national health crisis - Andrea Tone

multiple-choice.question: What was Frances Oldham Kelsey's role at the FDA when she began her fight against thalidomide?

options.label: A
options.text: She was the head of the FDA.

options.label: B
options.text: She was a new recruit at the FDA.

options.label: C
options.text: She was a researcher at the FDA.

options.label: D
options.text: She was a doctor at the FDA.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Frances Kelsey reject Merrell's application to sell thalidomide in the US?

options.label: A
options.text: She believed the drug was too expensive.

options.label: B
options.text: She found the data on thalidomide's absorption and toxicity inadequate.

options.label: C
options.text: She thought the drug was too widely used in other countries.

options.label: D
options.text: She believed the placental barrier shielded a fetus from harm.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of thalidomide being used by pregnant women?

options.label: A
options.text: It caused severe birth defects.

options.label: B
options.text: It caused nerve damage in the mothers.

options.label: C
options.text: It caused insomnia in the mothers.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no adverse effects.

multiple-choice.question: How did Merrell respond to Frances Kelsey's rejection of their application?

options.label: A
options.text: They provided the additional data she requested.

options.label: B
options.text: They complained that Kelsey was stubborn and nit-picking.

options.label: C
options.text: They withdrew their application immediately.

options.label: D
options.text: They launched thalidomide in the US without FDA approval.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Frances Kelsey's actions regarding thalidomide?

options.label: A
options.text: Thalidomide was approved for use in the US.

options.label: B
options.text: Thalidomide was pulled from the market in Germany, but not in the US.

options.label: C
options.text: Thalidomide was never approved for use in the US, and Congress passed laws to expand the FDA's authority.

options.label: D
options.text: Frances Kelsey was fired from the FDA.

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: To remove toxins from the body

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate blood sugar levels

options.label: B
options.text: Mitochondrial respiration

options.text: Sympathetic nervous system

options.label: D
options.text: Hypothalamic regulation

options.label: B
options.text: On the head and torso

options.label: C
options.text: On the arms and legs

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Radiation cooling

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: Why do people often sweat when they are sick or have a fever?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because the infection stimulates the hypothalamus to increase muscle activity, leading to heat production

options.label: D
options.text: Because the body is trying to regulate blood pressure

title: How does hibernation work? - Sheena Faherty

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why animals hibernate?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To conserve energy during periods of food scarcity

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate their body temperature

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.text: Female black bear

options.label: C
options.text: It slows down to about 1 to 3% of its original speed

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How do we study living brains? - John Borghi and Elizabeth Waters

multiple-choice.question: What are the three techniques used to study living brains without harming their owners?

options.label: A
options.text: EEG, fMRI, and CT scan

options.label: B
options.text: EEG, fMRI, and PET

options.label: C
options.text: EEG, CT scan, and PET

options.label: D
options.text: fMRI, CT scan, and PET

multiple-choice.question: What does EEG (electroencephalography) measure in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxygen consumption

options.label: B
options.text: Electrical activity

options.label: C
options.text: Blood flow

options.label: D
options.text: Radioactive elements

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of EEG in studying brain activity?

options.label: A
options.text: It is invasive and expensive

options.label: B
options.text: It is slow and cannot measure changes quickly

options.label: C
options.text: It cannot determine exactly where a particular pattern originates

options.label: D
options.text: It is not useful for diagnosing conditions like epilepsy

multiple-choice.question: What does fMRI (functional magnetic resonance imaging) measure in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Electrical activity

options.label: B
options.text: Oxygen consumption

options.label: C
options.text: Blood flow

options.label: D
options.text: Radioactive elements

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of using PET (positron emission tomography) scans in studying brain activity?

options.label: A
options.text: It is fast and can measure changes quickly

options.label: B
options.text: It is non-invasive and relatively inexpensive

options.label: C
options.text: It can study the complex chemistry in the brain

options.label: D
options.text: It can pinpoint differences in brain activity to within a few millimeters
